sense.name: act of measuring
sense.commentary: MEASURE[+event] measuring, mensuration - The act or process of measuring
sense.examples: The measurements were carefully done. His mental measurings proved remarkably accurate. The measurements took six days to complete.

sense.name: criterion
sense.commentary: standard, touchstone - a basis for comparison, a reference point against which other things can be evaluated
sense.examples: They set the measure for all subsequent work.

sense.name: amount
sense.commentary: quantity - How much there is of something that you can quantify
sense.examples: There was a large measure of lima beans in the bag.

sense.name: actions
sense.commentary: step - any maneuver made as part of a progress toward a goal
sense.examples: The situation called for strong measures. The police took measures to reduce crime.

sense.name: bill
sense.commentary: a statute in draft before it becomes law
sense.examples: They held a public measure on the bill.

sense.name: beat
sense.commentary: meter, metre, cadence, beat - the accent in a metrical food of verse
sense.examples: Shakespeare favored an iambic measure for his sonnets.

sense.name: bar
sense.commentary: musical notation for a repeating pattern of musical beats
sense.examples: The orchestra omitted the last twelve bars of the song.

sense.name: ruler
sense.commentary: measuring stick, measuring rod - measuring instrument having a sequence of marks at regular intervals, used as a reference in making measurements
sense.examples: George, you should've used a measure to draw the straight lines. The artist has unsteady hands and uses a measure to aid in all of his work.
